guide.introduction:
The MintDuino is perfect for anyone interested in learning (or teaching) the fundamentals of how microcontrollers work. It will have you building your own microcontroller from scratch on a breadboard, and then easily programming it from almost any computer via the Arduino programming environment.

Unlike pre-built microcontrollers, the MintDuino demonstrates the specific relationship between the wires, resistors, capacitors, and integrated circuits that enables you to program the microcontroller from your computer. After building the MintDuino, you'll have a much better understanding of how microcontrollers work, and how electronics can interact with the physical world.

lines.text: Start building your MintDuino by adding the 7805 power regulator. This converts the 9v power to 5v power that the ATMega can use.

lines.text: Now we are going to add one 10 uF capacitor to the power regulator.

lines.text: I like to trim the leads down so it doesn't stick so far out of the breadboard. One lead is longer than the other. The long lead is the (+) lead and the short one is the (-) lead. If you trim it, make sure to keep the lengths different lengths so it's easy to identify the (+) and (-) leads.

lines.text: The ATMega has a small "U"-shaped notch on one end. This notch lets you know where pin 1 is on the integrated circuit (IC) or "chip". If you hold the chip vertically, with the notch on top, pin 1 is directly to the left of this notch.

lines.text: Insert the IC so the notch is towards the power supply we already built.
lines.text_raw: Insert the IC so the notch is towards the power supply we already built.

lines.text: Insert pin 1 into "e9" as pictured.
lines.text_raw: Insert pin 1 into "e9" as pictured.

lines.text: You may need to bend the pins in a little bit so they don't flare out too much. You shouldn't need a lot of force to insert the IC.

lines.text: Time to add the crystal.
lines.text_raw: Time to add the crystal.

lines.text: The crystal is inserted into the breadboard at "b17" & "b18". Orientation isn't important; either way is fine.
lines.text_raw: The crystal is inserted into the breadboard at "b17" & "b18". Orientation isn't important; either way is fine.

lines.text: The crystal needs some capacitors to work properly. The two 22pF capacitors are not polarized, so orientation does not matter.
lines.text_raw: The crystal needs some capacitors to work properly. The two 22pF capacitors are not polarized, so orientation does not matter.

lines.text: Use one 22 pF capacitor (marked 220) and insert it into the the ground rail of the breadboard and "a17".

lines.text: While we are here, cut a 1/2" piece of black wire and connect the ground rail of the breadboard to "a16".
lines.text_raw: While we are here, cut a 1/2" piece of black wire and connect the ground rail of the breadboard to "a16".

lines.text: Time for more power!
lines.text_raw: Time for more power!

lines.text: Cut 3 pieces of red wire, all of them about 1/2" in length, and one black wire 1/2" in length.
lines.text_raw: Cut 3 pieces of red wire, all of them about 1/2" in length, and one black wire 1/2" in length.

lines.text: Use one red wire to connect the (+) rail of the breadboard to "j16"

lines.text_raw: Use another piece of red wire to connect the (+) rail of the breadboard to "j17"

lines.text_raw: Use one black wire to connect the (-) rail of the breadboard to "j15"

lines.text: Back to the other side of the board (by the crystal). Connect the remaining red wire from the (+) rail to "a15".

lines.text: Now let's wire up a status LED. This will help us know everything is working properly.

lines.text: Next connect the (-) ground rail of the breadboard to "j25" using a 220Ω resistor (red, red, brown).

lines.text: Now you have an LED connected to "pin 13" of the "Arduino". It's actually not pin 13 of the ATMega. The Arduino IDE uses different definitions for the pins to simplify its use. I'll go over the pins in the last step of the build.

lines.text: Now press the button into the breadboard. It only fits 1 way, so make sure the pins all line up properly. The four leads of the button will fit in "e6", "e8" & "f6" & "f8".

lines.text: Once they are centered, insert the 6 pins in column "b" from "b25 - b30" as pictured.

lines.text: Now we need to wire up the programming pins.
lines.text_raw: Now we need to wire up the programming pins.

lines.text: Cut three lengths of green wire (color may vary) approximately 2" each.

lines.text: It's a little hard to see. Make sure to double check all the wires.

lines.text: Next, add the 100nF capacitor (marked 104 on one side and K1K on the other) from "c25" to b23". It is not polarized, so inserted either way is fine.

lines.text: The final step is to add a 1/2" piece of black wire from "a30" to the ground rail (-) of the breadboard.

lines.text: All done! Now you can start programming the ATMega!

lines.text: To program your new MintDuino you need a USB -> serial connection.
lines.text_raw: To program your new MintDuino you need a USB -> serial connection.

lines.text: We suggest you use an FTDI Friend, but most FTDI cables will work.
